title: (x) Similar to Optima / stressed sans? - Peignot, Barbedor {Nina, Mark S}
content:
It is a "little" similar to Optima but the numbers are different, especially the "5".

The number "52".  
 [http://www.axisandallies.org/files/images/aap1940-3330.preview.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20100331013827/http:/www.axisandallies.org/files/images/aap1940-3330.preview.jpg)

I have a science fiction novel that has the same style of numbers, and it was printed back in 1983.

New Millennium Sans is a bit similar except for the numbers and being too recent.
author: Brimstone

comments.content:
The numerals come from [Peignot](http://web.archive.org/web/20100331013827/http:/new.myfonts.com/fonts/adobe/peignot/), but the lettering may actually be Optima. The lower case of the lettering shown in the table does not match Peignot, nor does the M.

- Mike Yanega

Yes, the letters aren't Peignot. I was only looking at the "52".  
The letters aren't Optima either though (looking at "MOBILIZATION ZONE") – the angles of the "M" are different and the "O" has what looks like diagonal stress.

It's too hard to see the details, but a pen-drawn font called [Amanda](http://web.archive.org/web/20100331013827/http:/new.myfonts.com/fonts/agfa/amanda/) seems to have similar shapes. I don't get the feeling that the lettering in the sample is quite so 'freehand' looking, but I can't think of a better stressed sans offhand.

- Mike Yanega
Nice one Mike – hadn't seen that before. I suspected Lydian. Thing is this mystery font (that we're maybe not even supposed to find ;-) has non-reversed stress in the "Z".

Maybe [Castle](http://web.archive.org/web/20100331013827/http:/new.myfonts.com/fonts/ef-typeshop/castle/) could be close?

- Mike Yanega
Thanks for the ID and the other suggestions. Very helpful!

It's hard to tell for sure from such a tiny sample, but I think the mystery font is [ITC Syndor](http://web.archive.org/web/20100331013827/http:/new.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/itc-syndor/). The M, Z and other characters seem to match.

You could be right Mark, but I never thought to consider small serif fonts. I can't SEE any serifs at all, but the image is small. Some of the lower case that you can guess at seems consistent too.

- Mike Yanega

Hmm... Wrong font but the right type designer (Hans Eduard Meier). I think it's actually [Barbedor](http://web.archive.org/web/20100331013827/http:/new.myfonts.com/fonts/ef/barbedor/?testdrive=custom%3D0%26dock%3Dfalse%26size%3D52%26w%3D720%26src%3Dcustom%26text%3DMOBILIZATION%2520Attack%26fg%3D000000%26bg%3Dffffff%26goodies%3D%26seed%3D19). Meier designed several faces with similar structure, but different details.
Yes, Mark is right: see the G in ‘Gun' and the y. Both are pretty distinctive – and match Barbedor. Good one!
Ahh, I thought I'd seen it before! Great one Mark.
